captions.text:
Queen Lion of the Animal Kingdom is displeased.
She recently introduced elections for the

office of king using the first post the post
voting system.

While her Realm started out as a healthy democracy
with many parties running candidates for king,

it quickly devolved into two party rule, with
the citizens not liking either one but trapped

within the system because of a problem called
the spoiler effect.

However, one of Queen Lion’s subjects from
a distant land, Wallaby, has a solution: The

Alternative Vote.
What’s the difference?

To find out, lets follow one voter on election
day, Red Squirrel, under both systems.

There are five candidates running for king,
two members of the big parties Gorilla and

Leopard and three other candidates, Turtle,
Owl and Tiger.

Under first-past-the-post Red Squirrel gets
a ballot where he picks just one candidate.

Red Squirrel Really likes Turtle and even
campaigned for him. However he knows that

his new neighbor, Grey Squirrel, is voting
Gorilla.

And what, starts to wonder Red Squirrel, about
all the other animals? Who are they going

to vote for?
The debates on Animal News Network only had

the big parties, so Red Squirrel thinks it’s
going to be a close race between Gorilla and

Leopard.
While he’s indifferent toward Gorilla he

is deathly afraid of Leopard.
Because he can only pick a single candidate,

he gives his one vote to Gorilla in hopes
of preventing Leopard from becoming king.

This is strategic voting, and it’s a necessity
under First Past the Post.

But now it’s time to look at the Alternative
Vote, which wallaby explains to Red Squirrel.

Instead of picking one and only one candidate,
he can rank them in order of his most favorite

to his least.
He goes into the voting both and gets the

same ballot as before, but now puts Turtle
as his first choice, Owl as his second and

Gorilla, third.
He dislikes Leopard and Tiger equally so he

stops filling in his ballot and drops it in
the box.

At this point, Red Squirrel doesn’t care
exactly what happens, he has other things

on his mind and heads off. But you, dear citizen,
want to know how the votes are counted so

here goes:
Turtle, beloved though he is with some of

the citizenry, comes in last place with only
5% and he is eliminated from the race.

Because the voters ranked their candidates
in order, we can know what would have happened

if Turtle didn’t run.
Without Turtle, voters like Red Squirrel,

would have picked Owl instead, so their votes
are transferred to her as though Turtle was

never in the race at all.
This is why Alternative Vote is sometimes

called Instant Runoff Voting. It’s able
to simulate a bunch of elections where the

least popular candidate is eliminated after
each round without all the time and expense

it would take to run a bunch of campaigns,
one after another.

The Alternative Vote method keeps eliminated
the least popular candidate until someone

either wins a majority or is the only one
left.

As no one has a majority yet, the next lowest
candidate, Tiger, is eliminated. Tiger voters

listed leopard as their second choice, so
she gets Tiger’s votes.

In the last round, Gorilla is eliminated.
Gorilla voters listed Owl as their second

choice, so Owl gets those votes, wins a majority,
so is crowed king.

The alternative vote is a better system because
it produces winners that a larger number of

voters agree on.
While the Alternative Vote does have flaws

it’s important to note that any problem
AV has, first past the post shares.

They’re both susceptible to gerrymandering,
they aren’t proportional systems, they can’t

guarantee a Condorcet winner (which math geeks
hate but there isn’t time to explain here),

and over time they both trend toward two main
parties.

That being said, Alternative Vote has a huge
advantage that first past the post lacks and

makes it a mathematically superior method:
no spoiler effect!

Imagine this election: the two big candidates
are running, Gorilla and Leopard, and Leopard

looks set to win 55% to 45%. But then a third
party candidate, Tiger, enters.

Tiger manages to convince 15% of the Leopard
voters to back him. Now the results are:

Under first past the post, gorilla now wins
even though a majority of the voters didn’t

want him.
Under the Alternative Vote, because all Tiger

voters put Leopard as second choice, Leopard
still wins because a majority of the citizens

of the animal kingdom would rather have her
in charge than gorilla.

With AV citizens can help support and grow
smaller parties that they agree without worrying

they’ll put someone they don’t like into
office.

After examining the differences, Queen Lion
decrees that the Alternative Vote is to be

the rule of the land for electing the king
and everyone is happier. …well almost everyone.

The two big parties can’t be complacent
and need to campaign harder for their votes.

This has been The Alternative Vote Explained
by me C. G. P. Grey.
Thank you very much for watching.

Exactly. Have it so that you rank your candidates (such as in AV) but 
without the discard-the-worst-candidate. That way, a candidate with many 
2nd choice votes but virtually no 1st choice votes can't just be thrown 
out. Have it so that it is based in a points system, where a 1st choice 
vote is worth 1 more than a 2nd, and so on. And if you like candidates 
equally, mark them equally and they all get the average amount of points. 
For example, after choosing your 1st and 2nd votes, there are 4 candidates 
left to rank, one of which you really hate. Mark the three you are 
indifferent to all as #3 (even though they will technically be filling the 
3,4, and 5 spots) and the candidate you hate as #6. The point system would 
look like this:
#1choice -> 5 points 
#2 -> 4
#3 -> 3
#4 -> 2
#5 -> 1
#6 -> 0

However, since you ranked those three candidates equally as number 3 
(taking up the 3,4 and 5 spots) they would each get the average # of points 
(3+2+1)/3 = 2 points for each of those while the candidate you hate gets 0.

Highest point total among all candidates wins. 

So you can still downgrade the candidate you hate without having to vote 
for the other big party. You don't need to fear voting for a small party 
and a weird scenario cannot occur where a string #2 choice candidate is not 
thrown out.

comments.text:
Very nice and simple explanation of the alternative voting method (also 
sometimes called preference voting). However, in reality, each animal 
doesn't uniformly list their preference as a block, as each individual 
individual voter's preference may vary and be divvied up differently.  Of 
course, it's much easier to illustrate the animal kingdom voting as a 
block, as they might represent groups of similar minded voters that would 
generally behave similarly. Obviously, a more progressive candidate is 
considerably less likely to vote for the polar extreme before exhausting 
preference as it nears the center, and vice-versa.  For more centrist 
minded voters, preference generally indicate a trend of preference falling 
to either side, either being skewed or more naturally distributed.  This 
system of governance would appear to benefit populists candidates, with 
candidates trying to capture the middle ground.

Ex. (With spectrum listed from progressive to conservative political 
leaning):

A: a a a – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 15%
B: b b b b – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 20%
C: c c c c c c – – – – – – – – – – – – – –  30%
D: d d d d d – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 25%
E: e e – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 10%

Let's say that A skews to the right, stopping at C (so 3 pref).
B Falls one either side, stopping at D (so 4 pref).
C Falls on either side, stopping at either A or E, and so on and so forth 
(mirroring the pattern above).

Instant runoff results 1 & 2 (A & E results redistributed).
A: – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 00% (-15)
B: a a a b b b b – – – – – – – – – – – – – 35% (+15%)
C: c c c c c c – – – – – – – – – – – – – –  30% 
D: d d d d d e e – – – – – – – – – – – – – 35% (+10%)
E: – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 00% (-10%)

Now the results are evenly split, the eventual result is in a more moderate-
progressive or moderate-conservative candidate (B or D) being elected, 
depending on how C voters preferences split (thus, this will inevitable 
result in a quasi 2-party, coalition system based).  Essentially, centrists 
decide the majority result (which is fitting since they have the greatest 
individual share of voters as a block).


In order to try and eliminate a 2 party trend, I recommend a variation of 
alternative voting, which I'll call blended result, which is like 
alternate, however each vote automatically goes to the 2nd tier, splitting 
accordingly (since no one won outright, no single party gains advantage). 
 I've tried to outline a splitting scenario, following the same initial 
results above, and the result (for this particular election and leanings of 
preference) is in a centrist candidate getting elected, again after the 
second round of preference voting: 

Ex.
1st pref instant run-off result (one possible scenario):
A: b b – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 10% (-15, +10%)
B: a a a c c c – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 30% (-20, +15%)
C: b b d d – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 20% (-20, +15%) 
D: e e c c c – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 25% (-20, +15%)
E: d d d – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 15% (-20, +15%)
(Note, D decided to veer slightly more conservative, splitting 2/3 for C 
and E).

2nd pref instant run-off result (one possible scenario):
A: b b – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 10% (b's from A and C evenly 
swap)
B: c c c – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – –  15% (c's b from B and D evenly 
swap)
C: a a a b b d d d e e – – – – – – – – – – 50% (a's & e's join swapped b's 
and d's)
D: c c c – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – –  15% (c's b from D and B evenly 
swap)
E: d d – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – – 10% (d's from C and E swap)
Result is C wins.

I think this represents a much more pure intention of the voters, in a 
result that is still very democratic (note that this particular election 
would have been a 3rd tier based election, which might feel less satisfying 
for individual voters, however it is still a much more broadly accepted 
result.  Further, in consideration of the C block being among the greatest 
individual share of voters, even though their votes were redistributed away 
from their candidate in subsequent instant run-off results, their candidate 
still won.  It's what I would consider democratically forced compromise n 
an otherwise split electorate.

This is just one possible outlines scenario, obviously, splitting might go 
very differently, depending on the number of candidates and voter interest, 
and preference might not extend broadly enough to reach some tiers (say if 
someone only voted for one or two candidates in preference, instead of 
more).  This could result in a less than 50% vote, should that happen in 
the blended election, the results would immediately default to the original 
alternate voting scheme.   

How is this a good system?  For clear voting results, block voting will 
still reflect the general trend of the country, while maintaining a 
democratic balance.  For close results, it forces a compromise system of 
governance (and far less partisan or divisive politics).   It's really a 
win-win.

That being said, even the American two party system has a sort of political 
valve that forces (although somewhat artificially) a balance towards the 
middle.  Primary systems unfortunately result in some very partisan 
candidates, which can be very off putting for more centrally minded 
individuals (especially closed primaries).  It is only towards the general 
election that such candidates start to tack towards the middle, and away 
from their party platforms, trying to gain the middle ground. 
 Unfortunately, this has the appearance of dishonesty and inconsistency, 
often leading to poorer candidates, whose main strengths may be how adroit 
and charismatic they may appear as they appeal more broadly to the 
electorate.  

Anyhow, these are my thoughts on the matter, and perhaps there are flaws 
with my blended alternative voting method (please share). However, as far 
as the US goes, I think any system that helps to encourage participation 
and cooperation rather than feed divisive and partisan political viewpoints 
would be an improvement.  There is far too much cynicism and vitriol 
polluting our political system, and I fear this only serves to weaken 
broader democratic representation in our system of governance.﻿
